title: How to get started with Angular
description: This will show you what you need to get started when you want to start using Angular
text: To get starter you need to do some installations. What you will need to get started will be : -Download your self a code editor i recommend to get Visual Code here is the link to it: Visual Studio Code -Download node.js and to do that you need to go to: Node.js ( get the current version). -Download git here is the link to it : Git-scm -Download Angular cli you can see the original page at Angular Cli This is not a normal install but a command that use node.js to do this you can use it in the command console just type "npm install -g @angular/cli" to install it. Then when you have everything installed you will be ready to start you new angular project. If you need a step by step you can always go to YouTube here is one that i really like

title: How to use variables in html
description: This is how to use a variable from the .js file inside the html
text: In all programming languages the variables represent some other value and you will want to use that variable inside of the html and since the variables should be in the .js file this is how you use it in the html while working with Angular.

content.text: This is what it will look like:

data:image/png;base64,
In this example we have the "{{ tittle }}" will replace the variable value and since it's in the .js file you can change it later on.

data:image/png;base64,

title: How to change variable in a component via html
description: This is how you would create a child component and change the variables in it from a parent component
text:
Angular is a component based architecture where you create a template and you just fill the values on them and you do this using variables.
Having that in mind you create a template and just change the content as needed and you do this by changing the variables in them and here is how!

content.text: To be able to change receive changes to it variables you need to import "Input " from @angular/core and add @Input() before your variable

//Template component html file

How To Angular!

Welcome to the {{ title }}
This would be how you would use the component in side of another
//Parent html file
As you can see the variable "title"  after the name of the component and it's set to "World!" changing the variable value in the template component

data:image/png;base64,
This time it's just a string variable but his can be done with any other type of data (boolean,number,etc..) and been a component you can use it as much as you want.
//Parent html file

data:image/png;base64,

title: How to use use angular basic commands
description: This will show you the most used commands while working in angular
text: When working in angular after you have Angular Cli installed there are commands that will help you speed up your working speed . Here are some of the ones i use the most: Note: the text in between " " should be replaced for your own name/path that you want to set. Create a new project: ng new "Project Name" This will create a new angular project at the current folder path that you have the console at(C:/SomePath). Open the current project in the browser: ng serve -o If you just type ng serve it will only enable the server for the project but you will have to open the browser and go to the http://localhost:4200/ the -o is telling the angular cli to --open the server in the browser after it is created. The official page for the cli commands is : Angular Cli But here are the ones used the most: Create a new Component ng g c "components/PathToSaveAt/TheNameOfTheComponent" The g is for generate and the c is for component. Create a new Service ng g s "service/PathToSaveAt/TheNameOfTheModel" The g is for generate and the s is for service. Create a new Model: ng g m "model/PathToSaveAt/TheNameOfTheModel" The g is for generate and the m is for module. Create a new Interface ng g i "model/PathToSaveAt/TheNameOfTheInterface" The g is for generate and the i is for interface. Create a new Enum ng g e "model/PathToSaveAt/TheNameOfTheEnum" The g is for generate and the e is for enum.

title: How to keep track of a component in the html
description: This is how to keep track of a child component you are using in the html file to change later on via code
text: Some times you will want to change many variables or change the variables or call a function in the child component via code.

content.text:
//Child Html

How To Angular!

Welcome to the {{ title }}

To be able to keep track of the child component you are using you need to use the "ViewChild " that is at @angular/core and add  @ViewChild() before the variable and giving it the name of the component ref  with @ViewChild('first')  where "first" is the ref tag you gave it in html file
To give it the ref id you use the # tag like in this example the #first ,#second ,#third
//Parent Html
Right the parent is looking like this since we are just changing the title variable

data:image/png;base64,
But now that we have the reference of the component in the parent .ts file we can do the changes via code.

Just make sure that you are using the reference only after angular has fully initialized. It will trow an error "ExpressionChangedAfterItHasBeenCheckedError" if the variable is been used in the child html .
For example when the user interacts with something like a button

data:image/png;base64,
After pressing the Change Values! button:

data:image/png;base64,
